strength.name: Gratitude
strength.description: Gratitude refers to appreciation for the benefits we receive from others and the desire to reciprocate with our own positive actions.

item.title: Dr. Robert Emmons of UC Davis talks about gratitude
What does gratitude look like?
item.content:
Those who demonstrate gratitude—and those who don’t—see life differently. Individuals demonstrating gratitude tend to emphasize language related to gifts, givers, blessings, fortune, fortunate, and abundance. Ungrateful people, on the other hand, tend to focus on deprivation, deservingness, regrets, lack, need, scarcity, and loss—what they are lacking rather than what they have. For instance, the grateful person might say, “I get to go to class today,” as opposed to, “Why do I have to learn all this useless stuff?”

Displaying gratitude looks like:

  • Recognizing what other people do for you
  • Showing appreciation for opportunities
  • Expressing appreciation by saying thank you
  • Doing nice things for people as a way of saying thank you

item.title: Keep a gratitude journal
item.content:
A group of researchers created an exercise in which individuals wrote down three good things that happened to them that day before going to bed. These can be large or small. Next to each, they jotted down why the good thing happened.
Another group of researchers suggest the following: “There are many things in our lives, large and small, that we might be grateful about. Think back over the past week and write up to five things that happened for which you are grateful or thankful.” Keep these reflections in a character journal and complete this activity at the end of each week.

item.title: Write a gratitude letter
item.content: The benefits of gratitude letters, along with examples of gratitude activities, can be found in the research of Dr. Robert Emmons, Dr. Chris Peterson, Dr. Martin Seligman, Dr. Sonja Lyubomirsky, and Dr. Jaime Kurtz. Spend fifteen minutes writing a gratitude letter to a person in your life who you have never properly thanked. This can be thanking him or her for something large or small. Try to be as detailed as possible about what you are thanking her for and the impact it had on you. If possible, deliver the letter in person and read it to them.

item.title: Train yourself to substitute grateful thoughts for ungrateful ones
item.content: Dr. Timothy Miller developed a four-step behavioral cognitive approach for learning gratitude: 1. Identify non-grateful thoughts. 2. Formulate gratitude-supporting thoughts. 3. Substitute the gratitude-supporting thoughts for the non-grateful thoughts. 4. Translate this gratitude into outward action.

item.title: Give back
item.content: Dr. Charles Shelton suggests reflecting on benefits and blessings in your life and considering ways to give back to others as an appropriate response for the gratitude felt. Naikan therapy, for instance, requires practitioners to reflect on what others have provided to them and what they have given back; in so doing, it creates feelings of gratitude, indebtedness, and the motivation to reciprocate.

item.title: Have even young children illustrate gratitude
item.content: Children are very visual. Have your child draw a picture of what he or she is thankful for today. You might even have them build a gratitude wall in their room by posting all the pictures that they draw over the course of a month. Try to include discussion of the pictures and the wall in everyday conversations.
